context: Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty and tonsillectomy. The patient with a history of obstructive sleep apnea who has been using CPAP, however, he was not tolerating used of the machine and requested a surgical procedure for correction of his apnea.

Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty and tonsillectomy. The patient with a history of obstructive sleep apnea who has been using CPAP, however, he was not tolerating used of the machine and requested a surgical procedure for correction of his apnea.
Obstructive sleep apnea.
The patient with a history of obstructive sleep apnea who has been using CPAP, however, he was not tolerating used of the machine and requested a surgical procedure for correction of his apnea.
General endotracheal tube.
41-year-old
gentleman
After all risks, benefits, and alternatives have been discussed with the patient, informed consent was obtained.
The patient was rotated 90 degrees away and a shoulder roll was placed and a McIvor mouthgag was inserted into the oral cavity.
Correct inspection and palpation did not reveal evidence of a bifid uvula or submucosal clots.

text: Allis forceps applied to the superior pole
context: Attention was directed first to the right tonsil in which a curved Allis forceps was applied to the superior pole.

text: Bovie cautery used to incise the mucosa of the anterior tonsil
context: The needle-tip Bovie cautery was used to incise the mucosa of the anterior tonsillar pillar.

text: Allis forceps to dissect the tonsil from fascial attachments
context: nce the tonsillar pillar was identified and the superior pole was released, the curved forceps with a straight Allis forceps and the dissection was carried down inferiorly, dissecting the tonsil free from all fascial attachments.
Once the tonsil was delivered from the oral cavity, hemostasis was obtained within the tonsillar fossa utilizing suction cautery.
Once all bleeding was controlled, the mucosa of both the hard and soft palate was anesthetized with a mixture of 1% lidocaine and 1:50000 epinephrine solution.

text: Posterior pillar clapped and taken down with Metzenbaum scissors
context: Now attention was directed to the posterior pillars. A hemostat was used to clamp the posterior pillar, which was then taken down with Metzenbaum scissors.

text: 3-0 PDS to approximate the anterior and posterior pillar
context: The posterior pillar was then approximated to the anterior pillar with the use of #3-0 PDS suture so as to create a box shaped soft palate.

text: Mucosa incised using a  #12 blade scalpel
context: Now, the uvula was reflected onto the soft palate and #12 blade scalpel was used to incise the mucosa of the soft palate extending down onto the uvula. T
The mucosa was dissected off with the use of Potts scissors

text: uvula reflected, and sutured down using 3-0 PDS
context: Now the uvula was reflected onto the soft palate and sutured down in place with use of #3-0 PDS suture approximated with deep muscle layers. Now the mucosa of the soft palate and the uvula were approximated with interrupted #3-0 PDS sutures.

text: 4-0 vicryl placed to secure the uvula
context: Finally, #4-0 Vicryl sutures were placed intermittently between the PDS to further secure the uvula, which had been reflected onto the soft palate.

text: 3-0 PDS to approximate the anterior and posterior pillars
context: A final #3-0 PDS suture was used to further approximate the anterior and posterior tonsil pillars.
Final inspection did not reveal any further bleeding.

text: Mouth irrigated and suctioned post procedure
context: The mouth was then irrigated with saline and suctioned. At this point, the procedure was complete.

At this point, the procedure was complete. He was awakened and taken to recovery room in stable condition. He will be admitted as an observation patient to the Telemetry Floor for routine postoperative management.
Of note, IV Decadron was administered during the procedure.
